awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Rheometer for Interdisciplinary Material Science Research and Training of Undergraduate Researchers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award, from the Major Research Instrumentation program, supports the University of San Diego's acquisition of a rheometer. Rheometers are routinely used to study the flow and deformation of soft materials (for example, gels) as a function of applied force and time. Rheometers measure properties such as viscosity, which is a measure of resistance to flow. For instance, water flows easier than honey, so it has a lower viscosity. Viscoelastic materials are those that exhibit both viscous and elastic characteristics under deformation. The rheometer to be acquired is capable of precisely controlling sample temperature, and it also provides direct microscopic visualization of samples under flow.  The rheometer also is equipped with tools to measure the tensile and bending strength of solid materials. This instrument will enable the University of San Diego faculty to conduct cutting-edge research on topics related to the behavior of biopolymers (for example, DNA solutions) and antibacterial materials. The rheometer will be used to provide hands-on training of undergraduates across different disciplines such as bioengineering and physics. The instrument also will enable the development of a new interdisciplinary course on biomaterials.

A state-of-the-art rheometer equipped with multiple accessories will accommodate diverse research and teaching needs at the University of San Diego, a primarily undergraduate teaching institution. This instrument will significantly advance four specific projects at the University of San Diego. First, it will be used to answer questions on how fluid-fluid phase separation is influenced by shear. Second, it will measure the mechanical properties of starch hydrogels which are used to deliver antimicrobial agents. Third, it will determine how the rheological properties of seawater are altered by mucous secretions and aggregates of microorganisms. Finally, it will measure the viscoelastic properties of biomaterials including cytoskeletal networks and entangled DNA solutions. These main projects, as well as others at the University of San Diego and at neighboring institutions, will be advanced substantially by this state-of-the-art rheometer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the acquisition of a state-of-the-art rheometer, a Discovery Hybrid Rheometer (DHR-3) from TA Instruments, to advance research by an interdisciplinary team at the University of San Diego, a primarily undergraduate institution. Researchers from physics, biophysics, chemistry, and environmental and ocean sciences used the rheometer in investigations of a broad range of systems from colloidal gels to biological fluids. The rheometer has significantly advanced the research agendas of multiple faculty members at USD, led to new research directions, provided multiple research opportunities for undergraduate students, facilitated collaborations with external scientists, and spurred the creation of new projects for undergraduate students in upper division laboratory courses.

Intellectual Merit: By enabling the purchase of an advanced rheometer, this project has advanced knowledge on multiple fronts. We investigated the rheological properties of colloidal gels and found that shear flow can be used to tune the structure of colloidal gels at both the micro and macro scales. We discovered how to form shear-induced flocs of colloidal particles by varying the interparticle attraction and shear rates. We investigated the rheological properties of polymeric fluids using DNA molecules of different topologies. We found that the viscoelasticity of such solutions depends strongly on the DNA topology and that the rheological properties can be tuned in situ using restriction endonucleases that digest DNA. We investigated the rheological properties of suspensions of phytoplankton in sea water. We found that viscoelastic properties of such suspensions depend on the marine aggregates formed from phytoplankton and that shear flow can alter the physical structure of these aggregates.

Broader Impacts: The investigations of a broad range of systems have revealed how rheological properties can be tuned. Such work could lead to novel materials for applications from construction to health care. Importantly, this work has involved numerous undergraduate students who have been exposed to the interdisciplinary field of rheology. Over a dozen undergraduate students have been trained to use the rheometer. Eight undergraduate students have been co-authors on papers that resulted from work using the rheometer. There have been 10 research presentations by undergraduate students on work studying the rheological properties of diverse materials. Finally, we have created projects involving the rheometer to be used in upper division laboratory courses for undergraduate students at the University of San Diego. These projects will expose even more students to the field of rheology.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2023
Modified by: Ryan Mcgorty
